summary: Parathyroid carcinoma is a rare cancer that forms in the parathyroid glands, which are responsible for producing parathyroid hormone (PTH) to regulate calcium and phosphorous levels. It can develop from parathyroid adenoma and is characterized by excessive PTH secretion leading to hypercalcemia.
causes: External radiation exposure (associated, but more common with adenoma)
diagnosis: Sestamibi parathyroid scan (intense radioactivity, no washout)
High parathyroid hormone concentration in blood (in those > 40 years)
High levels of HCG (suggestive in context)
treatments: Aggressive excision (including thyroid and surrounding tissues if necessary)
Calcimimetics (e.g., cinacalcet) to lower calcium levels
